Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I just don't know how I would cope with complete hair loss.  I was 'lucky' in that I had a mastectomy but no chemo.  Phew!    I do have rheumatoid arthritis which means taking chemo drugs at small levels but my hair has got so sparse.  Its a drag. I agree that this campaign is highly upsetting and I think MacMillan's should get some real cancer sufferers on board.  I think they would know best.  I thought the response given by the campaign team rep was appalling.  They should step down due to lack of understanding and empathy.  That's putting it politely. Sharon
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I am quite moved by all of the solidarity this has created.  Its good to know we are strong and able to speak out when we feel the need.  I hate being called a cancer 'victim' or 'brave' or made to feel I am weak and need others' sympathy.  I do want empathy.  I am not a victim and I am not brave.  I am certainly not weak.  I don't need people shaving heads to pacify poor little me.   Sharon

Posts.Content: Hi Ann I have just joined this group and finding it a bit new and difficult to find what I want but I found your entry and it would be so helpful to know how things have turned out for you.   I had breast cancer many years ago in the 80s and was left with a bad cosmetic result after having inplants put in.  I have been trying for years to see if I can get some improvement but so far without success.  This week I saw another plastic surgeon who has suggested that I consider this flap operation which you describe.  I know nothing about it and will obviously research all I can.  But I wonder if you had it done and what the outcome was?  I understand it can be a great success but also it can go the opposite.  So its a scary decision to make.  I wonder if you could contact me and chat about it and I would just like to know how you are anyway.   Best wishes Sharon
